section.title: The Invertible Matrix Theorem
section.p: This section consists of a single important theorem containing many equivalent conditions for a matrix to be invertible. This is one of the most important theorems in this textbook. We will append two more criteria in .

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let T\colon\R^n\to\R^n be the matrix transformation T(x) = Ax. The following statements are equivalent:
A is invertible.
A has n pivots.
\Nul(A) = \{0\}.
The columns of A are linearly independent.
The columns of A span \R^n.
Ax=b has a unique solution for each b in \R^n.
T is invertible.
T is one-to-one.
T is onto.

proof.p: (1\iff 2): The matrix A has n pivots if and only if its reduced row echelon form is the identity matrix I_n. This happens exactly when the procedure to compute the inverse succeeds.
(2\iff 3): The null space of a matrix is \{0\} if and only if the matrix has no free variables, which means that every column is a pivot column, which means A has n pivots. See this recipe.
(2\iff 4,\,2\iff 5): These follow from this recipe and this , respectively, since A has n pivots if and only if has a pivot in every row/column.

(4+5\iff 6): We know Ax=b has at least one solution for every b if and only if the columns of A span \R^n by this , and Ax=b has at most one solution for every b if and only if the columns of A are linearly independent by this . Hence Ax=b has exactly one solution for every b if and only if its columns are linearly independent and span \R^n.
(1\iff 7): This is the content of this .

section.p: To reiterate, the invertible matrix theorem means:

bluebox.p:
There are two kinds of square matrices:
invertible matrices, and
non-invertible matrices.
For invertible matrices, all of the statements of the invertible matrix theorem are true.
For non-invertible matrices, all of the statements of the invertible matrix theorem are false.

section.p: The reader should be comfortable translating any of the statements in the invertible matrix theorem into a statement about the pivots of a matrix.

remark.title: Other Conditions for Invertibility
remark.p: The following conditions are also equivalent to the invertibility of a square matrix A. They are all simple restatements of conditions in the invertible matrix theorem.

ol.li: The reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix I_n.
Ax=0 has no solutions other than the trivial one.
The columns of A form a basis for \R^n.
Ax=b is consistent for all b in \R^n.

section.p: Now we can show that to check B = A\inv, it's enough to show AB=I_n or BA=I_n.

corollary.title: A Left or Right Inverse Suffices

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n matrix, and suppose that there exists an n\times n matrix B such that AB=I_n or BA=I_n. Then A is invertible and B = A\inv.

proof.p:
Suppose that AB = I_n. We claim that T(x)=Ax is onto. Indeed, for any b in \R^n, we have
b = I_nb = (AB)b = A(Bb),
so T(Bb) = b, and hence b is in the range of T. Therefore, A is invertible by the . Since A is invertible, we have
A\inv = A\inv I_n = A\inv (AB) = (A\inv A)B = I_n B = B,
so B = A\inv.

Now suppose that BA = I_n. We claim that T(x) = Ax is one-to-one. Indeed, suppose that T(x) = T(y). Then Ax = Ay, so BAx = BAy. But BA = I_n, so I_nx = I_ny, and hence x=y. Therefore, A is invertible by the . One shows that B = A\inv as above.

section.p: We conclude with some common situations in which the invertible matrix theorem is useful.

solution.p: The second column is a multiple of the first. The columns are linearly dependent, so A does not satisfy condition 4 of the . Therefore, A is not invertible.

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n matrix and let T(x) = Ax. Suppose that the range of T is \R^n. Show that the columns of A are linearly independent.

solution.p: The range of T is the column space of A, so A satisfies condition 5 of the . Therefore, A also satisfies condition 4, which says that the columns of A are linearly independent.

statement.p: Let A be a 3\times 3 matrix such that A\vec{1 7 0} = A\vec{2 0 -1}. Show that the rank of A is at most 2.

solution.p: If we set b = A\vec{1 7 0} = A\vec{2 0 -1}, then Ax=b has multiple solutions, so it does not satisfy condition 6 of the . Therefore, it does not satisfy condition 5, so the columns of A do not span \R^3. Therefore, the column space has dimension strictly less than 3, the rank is at most 2.

statement.p: Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix such that Ax=b is inconsistent some vector b. Show that Ax=b has infinitely many solutions for some (other) vector b.

solution.p: By hypothesis, A does not satisfy condition 6 of the . Therefore, it does not satisfy condition 3, so \Nul(A) is an infinite set. If we take b=0, then the equation Ax=b has infinitely many solutions.
